thread.title: Wall Street slumps on Wal-Mart, data
thread.title_full: Wall Street slumps on Wal-Mart, data | Business Spectator

author: Dow Jones Newswires with a staff reporter
title: Wall Street slumps on Wal-Mart, data
text:
US stocks' losses deepened in afternoon trade after Wal-Mart Stores issued a gloomy earnings forecast, sending its stock tumbling.
At the closing bell, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 157 points, or 0.9 per cent to 16,925. Wal-Mart tumbled 10 per cent.
The retailer surprised investors by predicting a sharp drop in earnings next year, citing in large part its pledge to raise wages for most US workers and efforts to lift online sales.
Wal-Mart's move lower shaved over 40 points off the Dow.
The S&P 500 ended down 0.5 per cent, while the Nasdaq Composite lost 0.3 per cent.
The news came after data showing weaker-than-expected US retail sales growth of 0.1 per cent in September.
Investors were also grappling with mixed earnings reports.
"We had some mixed numbers," Kenny Polcari, director at O'Neil Securities, referring to earnings reports, said.
Intel shares gained 1.7 per cent despite the chip-supplier reported a more than 6 per cent drop in third-quarter profit.
JP Morgan Chase shares dropped 3.1 per cent after the bank missed analysts' third-quarter estimates. JP Morgan reported after market close on Tuesday.
Bank of America shares rose 0.7 per cent after the bank beat analysts' expectations for third-quarter earnings.
Investors also eyed the Federal Reserve's Beige Book, which detailed "modest" growth in much of the country.
European shares followed Asian markets lower after data showed lower-than-expected Chinese inflation in September, a day after disappointing import and export data from China dented stocks around the world. The consumer price index rose 1.6 per cent in September from a year earlier, compared with a 2 per cent rise in August.
The Stoxx Europe 600 was down 0.4 per cent, deepening losses from the prior session.
Most Asian indexes declined amid fears Beijing would miss its year-end growth target. The Shanghai Composite Index closed 0.9 per cent lower, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lost 0.7 per cent and Japan's Nikkei Stock Average fell 1.9 per cent. China's third-quarter growth figures are due for release on Monday.
Chinese markets had initially rallied as the data propped up expectations for new stimulus measures, though the optimism quickly waned.
"Fears of imminent financial catastrophe were overdone. But most people see that the growth capacity of the global economy probably diminished over the summer," Guy Foster, head of research at wealth manager Brewin Dolphin, said.
In commodities, gold prices climbed 1.2 per cent to $US1,179.80 a troy ounce.
Brent crude oil was down 0.2 per cent at $US49.15 a barrel.
